comments:
This course offers a brief review of high school calculus, applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, and Taylor's theorem. It is also an introduction to the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.

Students felt that this course was “interesting” and that they gained a lot of knowledge from taking the course. Because of the extent of the material covered, several students commented on the “fast” pace of the course. There was also a general agreement that “it would be much more beneficial if the classes were smaller.”

Students agreed that Professor Pemantle was very knowledgeable and a “nice guy.” However, many were disappointed with his teaching style. Students felt that Professor Pemantle moved way too quickly and “had a hard time effectively explaining problems.” Students also complained that the professor assumed a level of prior knowledge that they had not attained, and that the assigned homework problems were so difficult as to be “impossible.”

Students found the common exams given in this course to be “extremely difficult,” though they were curved. Several complained about a disconnect in the level of difficulty between homework assigned throughout the semester on the one hand, and the so-called “supplemental problems” and midterms on the other. A common suggestion from students in any section was to review Professor Rimmer’s online slides as a study aid.

This course offers a brief review of high school calculus, applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, and Taylor's theorem. It is also an introduction to the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.

Students felt that this course was “interesting” and that they gained a lot of knowledge from taking the course. Because of the extent of the material covered, several students commented on the “fast” pace of the course. There was also a general agreement that “it would be much more beneficial if the classes were smaller.”

Students raved about Professor Rimmer’s teaching ability. The most common word used to describe him as a professor was “excellent.” One student even wrote, “Rimmer is the best professor I’ve had at Penn.” Several commented on his enthusiasm and passion for the subject, as well as his availability to students.

Students found the common exams given in this course to be “extremely difficult,” though they were curved. Several complained about a disconnect in the level of difficulty between homework assigned throughout the semester on the one hand, and the so-called “supplemental problems” and midterms on the other. A common suggestion from students in any section was to review Professor Rimmer’s online slides as a study aid.

Students felt that this course was “interesting” and that they gained a lot of knowledge from taking the course. Because of the extent of the material covered, several students commented on the “fast” pace of the course. There was also a general agreement that “it would be much more beneficial if the classes were smaller.”

Students described Professor Zhu as “very thorough” and “approachable and willing to help explain things.” Several commented on her willingness to answer students’ questions. Though some students described the homework assigned as “extremely difficult,” others thought that it was “reasonable.”

Students found the common exams given in this course to be “extremely difficult,” though they were curved. Several complained about a disconnect in the level of difficulty between homework assigned throughout the semester on the one hand, and the so-called “supplemental problems” and midterms on the other. A common suggestion from students in any section was to review Professor Rimmer’s online slides as a study aid.

Students felt that this course was “interesting” and that they gained a lot of knowledge from taking the course. Because of the extent of the material covered, several students commented on the “fast” pace of the course. There was also a general agreement that “it would be much more beneficial if the classes were smaller.”

While students thought that Professor Krieger was very knowledgeable, some students felt that he “moved too fast” and was “difficult to understand.” Several also complained that he would jump several steps ahead when demonstrating problems on the board without explaining them.

Students found the common exams given in this course to be “extremely difficult,” though they were curved. Several complained about a disconnect in the level of difficulty between homework assigned throughout the semester on the one hand, and the so-called “supplemental problems” and midterms on the other. A common suggestion from students in any section was to review Professor Rimmer’s online slides as a study aid.

This course offers a brief review of high school calculus, applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, and Taylor's theorem. It is also an introduction to the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.

Students felt that this course was “interesting” and that they gained a lot of knowledge from taking the course.
Because of the extent of the material covered, several students commented on the “fast” pace of the course. There was also a general agreement that “it would be much more beneficial if the classes were smaller.”

Students generally felt that though Professor Sesum was knowledgeable and helpful during office hours, her teaching style in class was not conducive to learning. Several complained that she moved too quickly and “did a poor job of communicating course material.”

Students found the common exams given in this course to be “extremely difficult,” though they were curved. Several complained about a disconnect in the level of difficulty between homework assigned throughout the semester on the one hand, and the so-called “supplemental problems” and midterms on the other. A common suggestion from students in any section was to review Professor Rimmer’s online slides as a study aid.

This course offers a brief review of high school calculus, applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, and Taylor's theorem. It is also an introduction to the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.

Students felt that this course was “interesting” and that they gained a lot of knowledge from taking the course. Because of the extent of the material covered, several students commented on the “fast” pace of the course. There was also a general agreement that “it would be much more beneficial if the classes were smaller.”

Students described Professor Nicoara as “a great instructor.” Students were pleased with her method of solving problems step by step on the blackboard and felt that they were able to keep up. Many commented on her willingness to answer students’ questions. As one student wrote, “She’s always available for help during office hours.”

Students found the common exams given in this course to be “extremely difficult,” though they were curved. Several complained about a disconnect in the level of difficulty between homework assigned throughout the semester on the one hand, and the so-called “supplemental problems” and midterms on the other. A common suggestion from students in any section was to review Professor Rimmer’s online slides as a study aid.

This course offers a brief review of high school calculus, applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, and Taylor's theorem. It is also an introduction to the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.

Students felt that this course was “interesting” and that they gained a lot of knowledge from taking the course. Because of the extent of the material covered, several students commented on the “fast” pace of the course. There was also a general agreement that “it would be much more beneficial if the classes were smaller.”

Students were not pleased with Professor Strain’s teaching style. Several complained that he would teach off of the PowerPoint slides provided by the textbook publisher without providing clearer explanations. Students did say that he was “very accessible” and “listened to input from the students.”

Students found the common exams given in this course to be “extremely difficult,” though they were curved. Several complained about a disconnect in the level of difficulty between homework assigned throughout the semester on the one hand, and the so-called “supplemental problems” and midterms on the other. A common suggestion from students in any section was to review Professor Rimmer’s online slides as a study aid.
